dt: {bc}a comparison of two otherwise unlike things based on resemblance of a particular aspect
{bc}resemblance in some particulars between things otherwise unlike {bc}{sx|similarity||}
{bc}{d_link|inference|inference} that if two or more things agree with one another in some respects they will probably agree in others
{bc}{d_link|correspondence|correspondence} between the members of pairs or sets of linguistic forms that serves as a basis for the creation of another form

{bc}correspondence or similarity in form or function between parts (such as the wings of birds and insects) of unrelated or distantly related species that is the result of {d_link|convergent evolution|convergent evolution} {dx}compare {dxt|homology||}, {dxt|homoplasy||}{/dx}

pt: {sc}likeness{/sc} {sc}similarity{/sc} {sc}resemblance{/sc} {sc}similitude{/sc} {sc}analogy{/sc} mean agreement or correspondence in details. {sc}likeness{/sc} implies a closer correspondence than {sc}similarity{/sc} which often implies that things are merely somewhat alike.

pt.t: a remarkable {it}likeness{/it} to his late father

pt: {sc}resemblance{/sc} implies similarity chiefly in appearance or external qualities.

pt.t: statements that bear little {it}resemblance{/it} to the truth

pt: {sc}similitude{/sc} applies chiefly to correspondence between abstractions.

pt.t: two schools of social thought showing points of {it}similitude{/it}

pt: {sc}analogy{/sc} implies likeness or parallelism in relations rather than in appearance or qualities.

quotes.t: He does, though, suffer from the occupational deformation of international relations specialists: an enthusiasm for ransacking the past in search of precedents, {qword}analogies{/qword}, patterns, and cycles that might explain the present and forecast the future.

People who do this call themselves "white-hat" hackers—good people who show other people their vulnerabilities. Take the following {qword}analogy{/qword}: I've designed a great new lock pick, and I'm going to give this great new gadget away to show everyone that the typical door lock is ineffective against my new pick.
Parts of the far-infrared sky look like colonies of spiders gone mad. The fine structure seen there is called cirrus, by {qword}analogy{/qword} with filamentary clouds on Earth.
It has often been said that movie stars are the royalty of America. (The better {qword}analogy{/qword}, really, is that the royals are the movie stars of Britain.)

et: Middle English {it}analogie,{/it} borrowed from Middle French & Latin; Middle French, borrowed from Latin {it}analogia{/it} "ratio, proportion, correspondence in the inflection and derivation of words, the use of this correspondence in word derivation," borrowed from Greek {it}analogía{/it} "proportion, relation, correspondence in the inflection and derivation of words," from {it}análogos{/it} "proportionate, conformable, {et_link|analogous|analogous}" + {it}-ia{/it} {et_link|-y:2|-y:2}
shortdef: a comparison of two otherwise unlike things based on resemblance of a particular aspect
resemblance in some particulars between things otherwise unlike : similarity
inference that if two or more things agree with one another in some respects they will probably agree in others

dt: {bc}to compare so as to find a likeness

dt.t: He {it}drew/made an analogy between{/it} flying a kite and fishing.

shortdef: to compare so as to find a likeness
